prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for dumping my gf after her unannounced backpacking trip
Ok so this happened maybe three days ago, but first some context.

Me and my (now ex) girlfriend of 3 years lived in a 2 bedroom apartment which I pay for by myself, as I make enough money to afford it and I didn’t want to trouble her by pressing her with a bill for a place that is a tiny bit out of her price range, instead we use a meter and pay the bill through my account, with her compensating her  spend.
 
We also have always been big on trust since both of us have been cheated on in previous relationships, and didn’t want to go through that again in this one.

The fact that I pay solely this apartment is important as it allows her to spend her money on things like more expensive gifts and the occasional excursion for us (which of course I pay in part for). Also the fact that we are big on trust means we tell eachother A lot about our lives and future plans.

Anyways, she was always a fan of these trips abroad and loved travelling, and for the most part our trips were always fun. However, about three days ago she announced that she had bought tickets for a solo backpacking trip across South America which she was going to go on on Friday, and that she had been planning this for months.

First I asked if I could come, to which she said no because she would be “discovering herself” on this trip, and when I asked why hadn’t she told me she said because I wouldn’t have allowed (or at the very least not wanted) her to go, especially alone.  (Which is mostly true)

Well an argument ensued and at some point I finally put my foot down, it went something like this: 

Gf: “why can’t I just go explore the world and live life to its fullest”

Me: “you can, without me or the security of my home, pack your bags and get out”

I believe it was the right thing to do as she didn’t pay for the apartment anyways, and so didn’t have any right to demand to stay, plus I was willing to give her money for a hotel for a week, which she refused.

That night she went to her parents home an hour away and my phone was blown up with people calling me a controlling asshole and the like, my question is am I really an asshole for this?

TLDR: girlfriend popped a surprise solo trip on me 5 days before she left, saying she wanted to go alone and had been planning it for months, I kicked her out my house. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for dumping his girlfriend after she went on a solo trip. Let me break this down.

First, the situation: They've been in a 3-year relationship. The guy pays for the apartment by himself, which is a big point. They both value trust because they've been cheated on before. The girlfriend planned a solo backpacking trip across South America, which she hadn't told him about. She said he wouldn't have allowed her to go, which is probably true. When he confronts her, she argues she wants to live life fully, and he responds by telling her to leave the house. He offers money for a hotel, but she goes to her parents instead. Now he's wondering if he's an asshole.

Hmm. The key points here are communication, trust, and the living arrangement. She planned a trip for months without telling him. That's a big deal because they value trust and open communication. But then, when he finds out, he kicks her out of the apartment. The apartment is his, he pays for it. So legally, he can ask her to leave. But ethically?

The problem is that they live together in a two-bedroom apartment. Even though he pays for it, she's his partner. Maybe there was an unspoken agreement about living together. By kicking her out suddenly, he might have caused her to be homeless, even if he offered hotel money. Also, the way he handled it—during an argument—might be seen as harsh. He didn't give her a chance to resolve the situation, instead just told her to leave. That could be seen as controlling, even if he has the right to evict her.

But on the other hand, she kept a major life decision from him for months. That's a breach of trust. They both value trust, so her secrecy is a problem. He might feel that if she's not honest about something big like this, the relationship isn't working. However, instead of discussing it and maybe finding a compromise, he chose to end it abruptly. Maybe a better approach would have been to talk through the issue, address his feelings and her desire for independence.

Also, considering the living situation: if he's paying for the apartment, perhaps they had an understanding that she could stay there. Kicking her out without notice might be seen as unfair, even if he's the one paying. She might not have a place to go, and he did offer hotel money, but it's still sudden.

In terms of right or wrong: if the main issue is her keeping a big secret, he's justified in feeling betrayed. But the way he ended it—by evicting her during an argument—might come across as harsh. He could be seen as in the right for wanting honesty, but wrong for handling it poorly. The question is whether his actions were proportionate to the issue.

Another angle: mutual respect. If they value trust, he should address her secrecy calmly. Kicking her out might be a reaction driven by hurt or anger rather than a considered decision. So maybe he's in the wrong for not giving her the chance to explain or for not being more understanding about her need for personal growth. But she's also wrong for not communicating.

But the user wants a yes or no answer. The options are A (author wrong) or B (not wrong). Considering all that, the author's actions could be seen as wrong because he handled the situation poorly, possibly out of anger, and without giving her a chance to resolve it. Even though her secrecy is a problem, evicting her abruptly might be too extreme. So A might be the answer. But maybe B, because he has the right to his own home.
